author: Peter Weber, The Week US
title: Scientists grow beef cells in rice to make protein-rich hybrid food | The Week
text: Scientists create 'meaty' rice for eco-friendly protein Korean scientists have invented a new hybrid food, consisting of beef muscle and fat cells grown inside grains of rice What happened? Korean scientists said Wednesday they've invented a new hybrid food, consisting of beef muscle and fat cells grown inside grains of rice. The experimental "meaty" rice was developed to be an affordable and [eco-friendly](https://theweek.com/environment/climate-friendly-beef-is-another-instance-of-greenwashing) source of protein. Who said what? Integrating animal cells into rice could eventually "ensure a sufficient food supply" for "underdeveloped countries, during war, and in space," said the researchers at [South Korea's Yonsei University](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S259023852400016X#:~:text=The%20findings%20of%20this%20study,during%20war%2C%20and%20in%20space.). The commentary The "microbeef," as the researchers call it, "seems to be an early success" nutritionally and maybe taste-wise, too, Ed Cara said at [Gizmodo](https://gizmodo.com/scientists-create-beef-infused-rice-with-cow-cells-1851255552). This hybrid food research "holds promise for the development of healthier and more climate-friendly diets in future," said Neil Ward, an agri-food and climate specialist, in a [response statement to the study](https://www.sciencemediacentre.org/expert-reaction-to-study-looking-at-integrating-rice-grains-with-beef-cells/). But "while data on cost and climate impact look very positive, a critical test is around public appetite for these sorts of lab-developed foods."
